timeline.message:
Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/in-memory-sorting' into in-memory-sorting

# Conflicts:
#	hazelcast-jet-core/src/main/java/com/hazelcast/jet/core/Edge.java
#	hazelcast-jet-core/src/main/java/com/hazelcast/jet/impl/execution/init/EdgeDef.java
replace ComparatorEx by Comparator in SortPrepareP

timeline.bodyText: You may already have made progress by consuming some items in previous while loop iterations.
timeline.author: mtopolnik

timeline.message: fix returning NO_PROGRESS whenever a queue returns null

timeline.bodyText: we could add a reference back to monoticOrder here
timeline.author: cangencer
cangencer
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -66,6 +67,22 @@
     @Nonnull @Override
     BatchStage<T> rebalance();
 
+    /**
+     * Attaches a stage that sorts items based on their natural ordering.
+     *
+     * @since 4.3
+     */
+    @Nonnull
+    BatchStage<T> sort();
+
+    /**
+     * Attaches a stage that sorts the items based on user-defined comparator.
+     *
+     * @since 4.3
+     */
+    @Nonnull
+    BatchStage<T> sort(@Nonnull ComparatorEx<T> comparator);

timeline.bodyText: should use T here instead of V
timeline.author: cangencer

timeline.bodyText: I don't think using SortedSet is correct here. It will skip duplicates. PriorityQueue would be more correct.
timeline.author: cangencer
ufukyilmaz

timeline.bodyText:
Can you explain which kind of input data this processor can effectively sort (It seems to me that it cannot sort the streaming data completely, but I'm not sure.)?
Is this processor's only use case to sort the data completely or can it be used for other purposes such as partial sorting?
Also, could you document what the comparator parameter does and what the type parameter is?
timeline.author: ufukyilmaz
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -972,6 +976,22 @@ private Processors() { (singletonTraverser, service, item) -> flatMapFn.apply(service, item)); } + /** + * Returns a supplier of processors for a vertex that sorts its input using + * a {@link PriorityQueue} and emits it in the {@code complete} phase. + *

+ * The output edge of this vertex should be {@link Edge#distributed + * distributed} {@link Edge#monotonicOrder monotonicOrder} {@link + * Edge#allToOne allToOne} so it preserves the ordering when merging + * the data from all upstream processors. + * + * @since 4.3

replies.bodyText: Also, we should change V to T for consistency.
replies.author: mtopolnik

replies.bodyText: It's only meant for batch use cases, it's not meant to be available in StreamingStage interface.
replies.author: MohamedMandouh

replies.bodyText: I think we should add this information to this processor's javadoc.
replies.author: ufukyilmaz

replies.bodyText:
Actually, this inspires adding a new Edge property that's a limit on the number of items allowed to travel over it.
This simple change introduces partial sorting to Jet!
usage:
items.partialSort(10),
items.partialSort(ComparatorEx.reverseOrder(), 10)
replies.author: MohamedMandouh

replies.bodyText:
I guess partial sorting could still be done using stage.sort().aggregate(topN()) or stage.sort().aggregate(bottomN()).
But that means sending all data first to the target member that does global sorting to complete the sorting stage then choosing top or bottom N items from them which should be cost more comparing to only retrieving the N items you want from other cluster members.
Also because topN() and bottomN() will sort the data again at the target member by inserting the already sorted data in a priority queue which is added cost.
That's why I suggested introducing stage.partialSort()
replies.author: MohamedMandouh

timeline.bodyText: Public APIs should include a detailed explanation, sample usage, and parameter and return value descriptions. Could you add them? You can refer to the methods in the GeneralStage interface.
timeline.author: ufukyilmaz

timeline.message: add sample usage, param and return annotaitions
add "only available for batch" in javadoc
